queries.company_overview:
What it does: Meta Platforms operates Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Messenger, monetizing user engagement primarily through targeted digital advertising; it also develops AR/VR hardware and software via Reality Labs and invests heavily in AI infrastructure and foundation models.
Main business units / segments:
- Family of Apps (Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, WhatsApp; ads and other services)
- Reality Labs (AR/VR hardware, wearables, and related software)
High-level financials: FY2024 revenue $164.501B; net income $62.360B (USD; Meta press release 2025-01-29). Market capitalization $1.888T as of 2025-10-28 (USD).
Competitive positioning: Meta is one of the largest digital advertising platforms by scale across social and messaging, competing with Alphabet (Google/YouTube), ByteDance (TikTok), Snap, and Pinterest. In AI assistants and models it competes with OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic, while Reality Labs competes in AR/VR with Apple and others. Meta’s large user base and first-party engagement data underpin ad targeting advantages, while ongoing investments in AI infrastructure and brand-safety verification on Threads seek to sustain performance.
Recent major news:
- 2025-10-22 Meta cuts roughly 600 jobs in its AI division to streamline Superintelligence efforts.
- 2025-10-16 Meta expands third-party ad verification to Threads with IAS and DoubleVerify.
- 2025-10-01 Meta says AI chat interactions will inform ad targeting outside EU, UK, and South Korea.
- 2025-09-25 Meta launches Vibes, an AI-generated short-form video feed in the Meta AI app and web.
- 2025-10-01 Meta schedules Q3 2025 results release for 2025-10-29 after market close.

What are Meta's 2025-2026 plans to open-.query: What are Meta's 2025-2026 plans to open-source future Llama versions versus keeping proprietary commercial variants?
What are Meta's 2025-2026 plans to open-.answer: Meta signals a two-track strategy for 2025–2026: continue releasing leading open-weight Llama models for broad commercial use, while being selective about open-sourcing its most advanced ‘superintelligence’ systems. Official statements emphasize commitment to openness (e.g., Llama 3.1 405B; Llama 4 Scout/Maverick downloadable), but Meta now says it will train a mix of open and closed models and may keep top-tier models proprietary or accessible only via Meta AI/APIs for safety and product reasons.

search_results.title: Zuckerberg signals Meta won’t open source all of its ‘superintelligence’ AI models
search_results.snippet: In a 2025 letter on “personal superintelligence,” Zuckerberg says Meta will be careful about what it chooses to open source, and a spokesperson adds that the company will continue releasing leading open models while training a mix of open and closed models going forward—indicating not all frontier systems will be open-weight.

search_results.title: Open Source AI Is the Path Forward | Meta
search_results.snippet: Zuckerberg reaffirms Meta’s commitment to open-source AI, announcing Llama 3.1 405B as an openly available frontier model and stating that future Llama models are expected to be the most advanced in the industry; he argues openness benefits developers, Meta, and the broader ecosystem.

search_results.title: The Llama 4 herd: The beginning of a new era of natively multimodal AI innovation
search_results.snippet: Meta makes Llama 4 Scout and Maverick available for download on llama.com and Hugging Face, while previewing the larger Llama 4 Behemoth and explicitly not releasing it yet—showing a tiered approach where some models are open-weight and the most advanced are held back or served via Meta AI.

How will Meta integrate Scale AI's servi.query: How will Meta integrate Scale AI's services post-investment to accelerate dataset curation and model evaluation in 2025?
How will Meta integrate Scale AI's servi.answer: Following Meta’s June 2025 minority investment, both firms said they will substantially expand their commercial relationship, with Meta deepening its use of Scale’s data solutions to produce training data and accelerate model development. Practically, this means plugging Scale’s Data Engine into Meta’s LLM pipeline for end-to-end dataset collection, curation, and annotation, and using Scale-run RLHF, red-teaming, and evaluation workflows to tighten feedback loops and speed model evaluation in 2025, aided by Alexandr Wang’s move to Meta’s superintelligence team.

search_results.title: Scale AI confirms ‘significant’ investment from Meta, says CEO Alexandr Wang is leaving
search_results.snippet: TechCrunch reports Meta’s multibillion-dollar stake in Scale AI and quotes Meta saying it will deepen the work the two do together producing data for AI models, while Scale’s CEO joins Meta’s superintelligence efforts—signaling tighter integration of Scale’s data-production workflows into Meta’s training pipeline.

search_results.title: Scale AI Announces Next Phase of Company’s Evolution
search_results.snippet: Scale’s press release states Meta’s investment will substantially expand the companies’ commercial relationship to accelerate deployment of Scale’s data solutions, and that Alexandr Wang will join Meta—indicating broader use of Scale’s services across Meta’s AI stack to speed data operations.

search_results.title: Data Engine: Data Annotation, Collection, & Curation Platform
search_results.snippet: Scale’s Data Engine outlines an end‑to‑end stack for dataset curation—collect, curate, and annotate data—and model evaluation via RLHF, red teaming, and evaluations to find and fix model weaknesses. These are the concrete services Meta can integrate to accelerate dataset curation and model evaluation in 2025.

How many AI researchers did Meta hire or.query: How many AI researchers did Meta hire or lose in 2025 across FAIR and Superintelligence Labs?
How many AI researchers did Meta hire or.answer: In 2025, Meta hired roughly 50 AI researchers for its new Superintelligence Labs (notably the TBD Lab). It then saw early attrition—at least eight staffers, including multiple researchers, left within weeks—and in October cut about 600 AI roles across Superintelligence Labs, impacting FAIR, product AI, and infrastructure teams (not all of these were researchers).

search_results.title: Exclusive: Meta slashes jobs in its AI operations
search_results.snippet: Axios reports Meta is cutting roughly 600 positions within its Superintelligence Labs, with the reductions affecting the FAIR AI research unit, product-focused AI, and AI infrastructure teams, while the newly formed TBD Lab continues hiring, according to an internal memo from Chief AI Officer Alexandr Wang.

search_results.title: Meta Superintelligence Labs is already losing key staff less than two months after launch
search_results.snippet: Business Insider says that less than two months after Meta launched its Superintelligence Labs, at least eight employees—including researchers—had left; Wired reported two researchers (Avi Verma and Ethan Knight) returned to OpenAI after under a month, and Rishabh Agarwal also departed shortly thereafter.

search_results.title: Meta's Superintelligence Lab Hit by Departures After Recruiting Spree
search_results.snippet: Observer reports Mark Zuckerberg hired roughly 50 new AI researchers at Meta in record time for the Superintelligence Labs (notably the TBD team), even as several recent hires and longtime staffers soon left, underscoring rapid hiring alongside early attrition.

What patent applications did Meta file i.query: What patent applications did Meta file in 2025 related to multimodal generation, recommendation, and privacy-preserving learning?
What patent applications did Meta file i.answer: In 2025, Meta filed and had published: (1) US20250104311A1 (Text to Image Changer), which uses machine learning and latent diffusion models to modify images based on text prompts—supporting multimodal generation/editing; (2) US20250053430A1 (Large language model-based virtual assistant for high-level goal contextualized action recommendations), which gathers user goals and context to prompt an LLM that produces personalized, contextual action recommendations—covering recommendation; and (3) US20250209383A1 (Systems and methods for federated learning), which employs a knowledge-graph to enforce data-sharing policies among local models, enabling policy-aware, privacy-preserving learning.

search_results.title: Text to Image Changer
search_results.snippet: Meta’s US20250104311A1 describes a method to modify a reference image using text input: an ML model detects image features and one or more latent diffusion models edit background, regions, or style according to the prompt, enabling text-guided multimodal image generation/editing (published Mar 27, 2025; assignee Meta Platforms, Inc.).

search_results.title: Large language model-based virtual assistant for high-level goal contextualized action recommendations
search_results.snippet: Meta’s US20250053430A1 details a virtual assistant that collects user high-level goals and context signals, forms a prompt for an LLM, and generates contextualized action recommendations presented via an assistant UI—an LLM-driven recommendation framework (published Feb 13, 2025; assignee Meta Platforms Technologies, LLC).

search_results.title: Systems and methods for federated learning
search_results.snippet: Meta’s US20250209383A1 proposes a federated learning system that builds a knowledge graph of nodes, datasets, and policies to determine permitted data-sharing paths; it selectively trains local models and updates a global model while enforcing privacy constraints—supporting privacy-preserving learning (published Jun 26, 2025; assignee Meta Platforms, Inc.).

Which external data partners supply Meta.query: Which external data partners supply Meta's Llama training corpus in 2025, and under what licensing terms?
Which external data partners supply Meta.answer: In 2025, Meta’s confirmed external data suppliers for Llama include Shutterstock and Reuters, along with rights-cleared datasets from brokers like Defined.ai. Shutterstock licenses its library (images, video, music) for AI model training under paid, rights-resolved agreements—initial Big Tech deals ranged from $25–$50M and have expanded, with contributor compensation and transparent IP transfer. Reuters has a multiyear content license with Meta to ground Meta AI’s outputs with linked attribution; the deal’s dollar terms are undisclosed and training rights for Llama weren’t specified. Defined.ai supplies ethically sourced, rights-cleared data to Meta under commercial licenses, with typical rates cited (e.g., $1–$2 per image; $2–$4 per short video; $100–$300 per hour of long-form video).

search_results.title: Big Tech cos in race to buy training data for artificial intelligence
search_results.snippet: Reuters reports that after ChatGPT’s debut, Meta, Google, Amazon, and Apple struck paid licensing agreements with Shutterstock to use hundreds of millions of images, videos, and music files for AI training—initially $25–$50M each and later expanded. The piece also notes Defined.ai licenses ‘ethically sourced’ datasets to Meta and others under per-asset commercial rates (e.g., $1–$2 per image; $2–$4 per short video; $100–$300 per hour of longer films), underscoring that Meta sources rights-cleared training data via commercial deals.

search_results.title: Shutterstock Expands Long-standing Relationship with Meta
search_results.snippet: Shutterstock says it will provide content to fuel Meta’s AI, with Meta using Shutterstock’s images, videos, and music ‘to develop, train and evaluate its machine learning capabilities.’ The company emphasizes contributor compensation and ‘responsible creation and licensing’ with transparent IP transfer—confirming a paid, rights-resolved licensing framework for training.

search_results.title: Meta inks multiyear AI content licensing deal with Reuters
search_results.snippet: Meta and Reuters confirmed a multiyear content license that lets Meta AI use Reuters articles to answer current-events queries with linked attribution. The dollar terms are undisclosed, and the story notes it’s unclear whether this agreement grants Meta training rights for Llama, but it establishes Reuters as a licensed external content partner.

What is Meta's 2025-2026 plan for MTIA d.query: What is Meta's 2025-2026 plan for MTIA deployment across inference workloads on Instagram and Facebook?
What is Meta's 2025-2026 plan for MTIA d.answer: Meta plans to ramp MTIA across ranking and recommendation inference workloads on Facebook and Instagram throughout 2025, building on 2024 deployments for ads and organic content. In 2026, Meta aims to extend MTIA beyond inference to support training for ranking/recommendations and begin supporting some generative AI use cases.

search_results.title: Meta Platforms, Inc. Q4 2024 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: Meta’s CFO said MTIA started rolling out in 2024 to ranking and recommendation inference for ads and organic content across its apps; Meta will further ramp MTIA adoption through 2025 for these inference workloads, then extend custom silicon to training for ranking and recommendations in 2026.

search_results.title: Meta moves forward on AI training chip
search_results.snippet: Citing Reuters and Meta’s Q4 2024 call, the article notes Meta will ramp MTIA in 2025 for recommendation inference across Facebook and Instagram feeds, and in 2026 expand MTIA to support some core AI training workloads and certain generative AI use cases.

search_results.title: Meta’s Second Generation AI Chip: Model-Chip Co-Design and Productionization Experiences
search_results.snippet: An ISCA’25 paper explains MTIA 2i is optimized for inference for recommendation models—the majority of inference at Meta powering Facebook and Instagram—and is already deployed at scale serving billions of users, underscoring its fit for these workloads as deployments ramp.

What is Meta's 2025 budget and timeline.query: What is Meta's 2025 budget and timeline for AI data center expansions and 400G optical upgrades?
What is Meta's 2025 budget and timeline.answer: Meta’s 2025 infrastructure capex is guided to $64–72B, raised to fund additional AI data center buildouts and higher hardware costs. Its AI expansion timeline includes multi‑GW clusters: the Prometheus supercluster is slated to come online in 2026, while Hyperion in Louisiana scales toward 5GW over several years (up to ~1.5GW IT by end‑2027, with full build‑out into 2030). For 400G optical upgrades, Meta has been deploying 200G/400G FR4 pluggables across its 25.6Tbps switch fabrics, with OCP materials showing quarter‑by‑quarter 200G/400G ramp and specs designed for backward compatibility and forward migration toward 800G.

search_results.title: Meta Reports First Quarter 2025 Results
search_results.snippet: Meta guides full‑year 2025 capital expenditures to $64–72B (including finance leases), up from $60–65B, citing additional AI data center investments and higher infrastructure hardware costs; the majority of 2025 capex remains directed to the core business.

search_results.title: Meta to invest "hundreds of billions of dollars into compute to build superintelligence," with several multi-GW data center clusters
search_results.snippet: Zuckerberg outlines a multi‑year AI buildout: the Prometheus AI supercluster comes online in 2026; Hyperion in Louisiana can scale to 5GW over several years, with up to ~1.5GW IT power by end‑2027 and full campus build‑out expected into 2030—illustrating the expansion timeline beyond 2025.

search_results.title: 200G/400G FR4 Large‑Scale Deployment in Meta’s Data Centers
search_results.snippet: Meta’s OCP presentation details large‑scale deployments of 200G/400G FR4 pluggable optics on 25.6Tbps switch fabrics; includes a “200G/400G Deployment by Quarter” slide showing the 400G rollout cadence, with specs optimized for backward compatibility and forward evolution toward 800G.

What is Meta Superintelligence Labs' 202.query: What is Meta Superintelligence Labs' 2026 foundation model roadmap and training compute requirements?
What is Meta Superintelligence Labs' 202.answer: Meta Superintelligence Labs plans to bring its first 1GW AI training supercluster, Prometheus, online in 2026 to support training of next‑generation Llama foundation models, with Hyperion scaling to 5GW in subsequent years and more multi‑GW “titan” clusters to follow. On compute needs, Mark Zuckerberg said training Llama 4 requires roughly 10x the compute used for Llama 3; Meta’s own technical post adds that Llama 4 Behemoth pretraining used around 32,000 GPUs at ~390 TFLOPs/GPU across more than 30 trillion tokens—illustrating the scale of training compute MSL is provisioning for.

search_results.title: Mark Zuckerberg says Meta is building a 5GW AI data center
search_results.snippet: Zuckerberg said Meta will bring a 1GW Prometheus AI supercluster online in 2026 and scale a second cluster, Hyperion, to 5GW over several years—part of a broader push to equip Meta Superintelligence Labs with industry‑leading compute per researcher to train frontier foundation models.

search_results.title: The Llama 4 herd: The beginning of a new era of natively multimodal AI innovation
search_results.snippet: Meta details Llama 4’s training scale: the Behemoth teacher model was pretrained using FP8 on roughly 32K GPUs achieving ~390 TFLOPs/GPU, with a data mixture exceeding 30 trillion tokens—signposting the training compute and data requirements underlying Meta’s current foundation model roadmap.

search_results.title: Meta to boost training infra for Llama 4 tenfold, maybe deliver it next year
search_results.snippet: On Meta’s Q2 2024 call, Zuckerberg said building Llama 4 would likely need almost 10x the compute used for Llama 3 (believed to be ~16,000 GPUs), underscoring the sharp increase in training compute MSL is planning for its next foundation model generation.

What are Meta's current 2025-2026 AI saf.query: What are Meta's current 2025-2026 AI safety evaluation benchmarks and red-teaming protocols for Llama models?
What are Meta's current 2025-2026 AI saf.answer: Meta’s current approach pairs open safety benchmarks with scaled red-teaming. For benchmarks, its Purple Llama CyberSecEval (now v4) evaluates insecure code generation, ATT&CK‑aligned attack assistance, prompt‑injection resilience (text and image), code‑interpreter abuse, plus offensive and defensive cyber capabilities, adding AutoPatchBench and CyberSOCEval in 2025. For red‑teaming, Meta runs systematic human and automated adversarial testing, including GOAT to simulate multi‑turn, medium‑skilled attackers, with findings fed back into post‑training; system‑level safeguards (Llama Guard, Prompt Guard, Code Shield/LlamaFirewall) are provided for deployment.

search_results.title: Llama Protections — Making protection tools accessible to everyone
search_results.snippet: Meta outlines its 2025 evaluation suite for Llama under Purple Llama CyberSecEval: tests cover insecure code generation (CWE), compliance with attacker requests mapped to MITRE ATT&CK, susceptibility to text/image prompt injection, code‑interpreter abuse, and both offensive and defensive cyber capabilities. CyberSecEval 4 expands with AutoPatchBench (automatic vulnerability patching) and CyberSOCEval (SOC reasoning), with open resources and code for developers; complementary safeguards include Llama Guard, Prompt Guard, Code Shield, and LlamaFirewall.

search_results.title: The Llama 4 herd: The beginning of a new era of natively multimodal AI innovation
search_results.snippet: Meta describes its current evaluations and red‑teaming for Llama 4: systematic, repeatable testing across scenarios; stress testing via adversarial dynamic probing; and a new automated Generative Offensive Agent Testing (GOAT) system to simulate multi‑turn, medium‑skilled adversaries. Findings from human and automated red teaming are fed into post‑training to harden models while maintaining capability.

search_results.title: Automated Red Teaming with GOAT: the Generative Offensive Agent Tester
search_results.snippet: Meta’s GOAT is an automated, agentic red‑teaming method that conducts multi‑turn adversarial conversations using diverse jailbreak techniques to identify LLM vulnerabilities efficiently. It achieves high attack success rates (e.g., ASR@10 ≈97% on Llama 3.1) and is designed to scale human red‑teaming by covering known risk areas more thoroughly while experts focus on novel threats.

How many NVIDIA H100/H200-class GPUs has.query: How many NVIDIA H100/H200-class GPUs has Meta contracted for delivery in 2025-2026?
How many NVIDIA H100/H200-class GPUs has.answer: Public disclosures imply Meta has secured on the order of hundreds of thousands of H100/H200-class GPUs for 2025, but has not published a specific 2026 contracted quantity. Meta said it would end 2024 with ~600,000 H100-equivalents, and expects to field more than 1.3 million GPUs by end-2025—implying roughly ~700,000 incremental H100/H200-class units in 2025. Industry tracking indicates H200 becomes NVIDIA’s primary Hopper shipment from 2H24 into 2025, so most 2025 deliveries should be H200; no firm 2026 unit figure is publicly stated.

search_results.title: Meta plans $60-65bn capex on AI data center boom, will bring ~1GW of compute online this year
search_results.snippet: Meta said it plans $60–65B of capex in 2025 and expects to field a fleet of more than 1.3 million GPUs by year-end 2025, reannouncing a 2GW+ data center build. This guidance implies very large 2025 GPU deliveries (hundreds of thousands of units) on top of its 2024 base.

search_results.title: Building Meta’s GenAI Infrastructure
search_results.snippet: Meta’s engineering blog states that by end-2024 it aims to include 350,000 NVIDIA H100s as part of a portfolio with compute equivalent to nearly 600,000 H100s. This establishes the 2024 baseline from which 2025 deliveries ramp.

search_results.title: NVIDIA’s Data Center Business Fuels Explosive Growth in FY2Q25 Revenue; H200 Set to Dominate AI Server Market from 2H24, Says TrendForce
search_results.snippet: TrendForce reports that from 2H24 onward H200 becomes NVIDIA’s primary shipment driver as H100 phases out, indicating 2025 shipments to hyperscalers like Meta will be predominantly H200-class. This supports that 2025–2026 deliveries to Meta are largely H100/H200-class without a specific 2026 count disclosed.

How will Meta monetize data from AI chat.query: How will Meta monetize data from AI chats while preserving user trust and compliance outside EU and UK?
How will Meta monetize data from AI chat.answer: Meta will begin using conversations with its Meta AI assistant as signals to personalize ads and content across its platforms starting December 16, 2025, rolling out in most regions but excluding the EU, UK, and South Korea for now. To preserve user trust and meet compliance expectations, Meta will notify users in advance, exclude sensitive topics (e.g., religion, health, politics, sexual orientation) from ad targeting, scope cross‑app use via Accounts Center, and offer Ads Preferences and feed controls—though there’s no full opt‑out beyond not using Meta AI.

search_results.title: Takeaways: Improving Your Recommendations With AI at Meta
search_results.snippet: Meta says that beginning December 16, 2025, it will use people’s voice and text interactions with Meta AI to personalize content and ad recommendations, with notifications starting October 7. Users can manage Ads Preferences and feed controls; sensitive topics like religion, health, politics, or sexual orientation won’t be used for ads, and cross‑app use is limited to accounts linked in Accounts Center.

search_results.title: Meta plans to sell targeted ads based on data in your AI chats
search_results.snippet: TechCrunch reports Meta will use AI chatbot conversations to target ads across its platforms starting December 16, applying globally except in the EU, UK, and South Korea. There’s no opt‑out, sensitive categories are excluded, and data from AI features (e.g., Ray‑Ban smart glasses and Vibes) may also inform ad personalization.

search_results.title: Meta just tied your private AI chats to its ad business. The next step? Designing bots that keep you talking, expert says

What EU investigations in 2025 target Me.query: What EU investigations in 2025 target Meta's ad practices, AI data usage, or DMA compliance obligations?
What EU investigations in 2025 target Me.answer: In 2025, the European Commission found Meta’s “consent-or-pay” ad model in breach of the DMA and fined it €200m, ordering changes within 60 days and warning of periodic penalties while assessing Meta’s revised “less‑personalised ads” option. The Commission also issued preliminary DSA findings that Meta breached transparency obligations by hindering researchers’ data access and by not providing user-friendly notice-and-action and effective appeals on Facebook and Instagram. Separately, Ireland’s DPC oversaw Meta’s plan to use EU users’ public posts to train AI, allowing a 27 May rollout with stronger transparency, an in-app objection mechanism, and ongoing monitoring.

search_results.title: Commission finds Apple and Meta in breach of the Digital Markets Act
search_results.snippet: The Commission decided that Meta’s ‘Consent or Pay’ advertising model violates the DMA because it did not offer users a less‑personalised but equivalent alternative and did not ensure freely given consent; it imposed a €200m fine, gave Meta 60 days to comply, and is still assessing Meta’s November 2024 ‘less‑personalised ads’ option with the possibility of periodic penalties for continued non‑compliance.

search_results.title: Commission preliminarily finds TikTok and Meta in breach of their transparency obligations under the Digital Services Act
search_results.snippet: The Commission’s preliminary view is that Meta (Facebook and Instagram) breached DSA transparency duties by making researcher access to public data overly burdensome and by failing to provide user‑friendly notice‑and‑action and effective appeal mechanisms; if confirmed, a non‑compliance decision could follow with fines up to 6% of global turnover and periodic penalty payments.

search_results.title: DPC statement on Meta AI
search_results.snippet: Ireland’s Data Protection Commission confirmed it engaged with Meta on plans to train AI on EU users’ public Facebook and Instagram content, secured safeguards (updated transparency, easier in‑app objection, de‑identification, filters, and revised risk assessments), did not block the 27 May 2025 launch, and is monitoring compliance with a report expected in October 2025.

How does Meta's AI infrastructure cost p.query: How does Meta's AI infrastructure cost per training FLOP compare to Microsoft and Google in 2025?
How does Meta's AI infrastructure cost p.answer: Based on 2025 public data, Google’s TPU-based stack has the lowest cost per training FLOP: Google Cloud pricing implies TPU v5e/v5p deliver roughly 1.2–1.8x more FLOPs per dollar than Nvidia H100 GPUs, i.e., lower $/FLOP. Meta’s training clusters are Nvidia H100–based (24.6k‑GPU clusters, scaling to ~350k H100s), so its $/training‑FLOP aligns with GPU economics and is higher than Google’s TPU pricing. Microsoft is rolling out its in‑house Maia 100 to improve cost efficiency versus third‑party GPUs, but public $/FLOP figures remain scarce; until Maia is broadly deployed, Microsoft’s $/training‑FLOP resembles GPU‑based economics.

search_results.title: Serving LLaMA 3-70B on TPUs
search_results.snippet: Published Feb 4, 2025, this section quantifies FLOPs per dollar using Google Cloud list prices: H100 at $10.8/h delivers ~3.3e17 FLOPs/$, TPU v5p ~3.9e17 FLOPs/$, and TPU v5e ~5.8e17 FLOPs/$. This shows TPUs provide more compute per dollar than H100, implying a lower $/FLOP for Google’s TPU stack compared with Nvidia GPU-based training.

search_results.title: Building Meta’s GenAI Infrastructure
search_results.snippet: Meta details two 24,576‑GPU H100 training clusters used for Llama 3 and targets 350,000 NVIDIA H100s (and ~600,000 H100‑equivalent compute) by end‑2024. This confirms Meta’s training infrastructure is Nvidia GPU‑based, so its cost per training FLOP tracks H100 economics rather than Google’s TPU pricing.

search_results.title: Inside Maia 100: Revolutionizing AI Workloads with Microsoft's Custom AI Accelerator
search_results.snippet: Microsoft describes its first‑gen in‑house AI accelerator Maia 100 as vertically integrated to optimize performance and reduce costs, with an Ethernet fabric up to 4.8 Tbps and liquid cooling. While no public $/FLOP is given, the stated goal is improved cost efficiency versus third‑party GPUs, indicating a push to lower Azure’s training $/FLOP.

In other words, Meta’s share is 37% compared with TikTok’s 55% and YouTube Shorts’ 26% for short‑form watch time inside each app.

search_results.title: Here's How Much TikTok Has Dominated Short-Form Video
search_results.snippet: Adweek summarizes Sensor Tower’s 2025 report: U.S. TikTok users spend 55% of their in-app time on short-form, Instagram users dedicate 37% of their time to Reels, and YouTube Shorts captures 26% of users’ time—contextualizing Meta’s Reels share versus TikTok and Shorts.

search_results.title: State of Mobile 2025
search_results.snippet: Sensor Tower’s authoritative 2025 report analyzing app engagement and time spent across categories; it underpins the cited in-app short-form watch time shares for TikTok, Instagram Reels (Meta), and YouTube Shorts.

search_results.snippet: In April 2025, Meta expanded Threads ads to all advertisers worldwide (reaching 320M+ monthly users) via a new Threads feed placement. This enables brands to reallocate spend into Threads, though no percentage is given for shifts from X or for tentpole periods.

search_results.title: Media Update: Ad-Supported Gaming, Threads Feature Rollout, Advertising Growth Outlook

How will Meta comply with EU AI Act risk.query: How will Meta comply with EU AI Act risk management for generative AI deployed in Meta AI and Vibes?
How will Meta comply with EU AI Act risk.answer: Meta will need to meet the EU AI Act’s transparency and risk‑management duties for generative and general‑purpose AI: disclose when users interact with AI (e.g., Meta AI), mark and label AI‑generated audio/video/images (including deepfakes), and as a GPAI provider publish technical documentation and a training‑data summary; if its models are deemed systemic, it must perform model evaluations, adversarial testing, incident reporting, and ensure cybersecurity. As a VLOP, Meta must also submit DSA risk assessments before deploying new features like Meta AI/Vibes in the EU. Meta has begun implementing provenance labeling and watermarking via C2PA Content Credentials across its platforms, aligning with the Act’s content‑marking obligations.

search_results.title: High-level summary of the AI Act
search_results.snippet: The EU AI Act imposes transparency duties for limited-risk systems (e.g., chatbots and deepfakes) and specific obligations on providers of general-purpose AI (GPAI): technical documentation, information for downstream deployers, an EU copyright policy, and a public summary of training data; GPAI models deemed systemic must also conduct model evaluations and adversarial testing, assess and mitigate systemic risks, track/report serious incidents, and ensure cybersecurity—key risk‑management steps that providers like Meta must satisfy for generative features.

search_results.title: Meta's AI tool still not cleared for use by EU Commission
search_results.snippet: The European Commission said it is awaiting Meta’s risk assessment under the Digital Services Act (DSA) before MetaAI rolls out EU‑wide, noting new functions require advance risk assessments in addition to annual filings. The report recalls Meta’s earlier EU delays over GDPR training plans and shows that, alongside AI Act duties, Meta must evidence risk mitigation and transparency measures to deploy features like Meta AI in Europe.

search_results.title: Meta Joins the C2PA Steering Committee
search_results.snippet: Meta has committed to Content Credentials (C2PA) and uses them to inform labeling of AI-generated images across Facebook, Instagram, and Threads, adding visible and invisible provenance signals so people know when AI was used. This adoption of standardized provenance/watermarking supports the EU AI Act’s requirement to mark and disclose synthetic content and provides a pathway to label outputs from generative features like Meta AI and Vibes.

How is Meta addressing India's 2025 digi.query: How is Meta addressing India's 2025 digital personal data protection rules across WhatsApp Business and ads personalization?
How is Meta addressing India's 2025 digi.answer: Meta says its regulatory readiness team is building an India‑specific consent experience to comply with the DPDP Act and forthcoming 2025 rules, and is seeking clarity on issues like profiling limits for minors, cross‑border transfers, and significant data fiduciary obligations. On WhatsApp Business, Meta enforces explicit opt‑in and requires businesses to obtain all notices and consents and comply with applicable law, aligning with India’s consent‑first regime. For ads personalization, Meta is adapting to a CCI order that bans WhatsApp‑to‑Meta data sharing for ads in India, warning it may need to pause features and cannot personalize Facebook/Instagram ads based on WhatsApp interactions.

search_results.title: Meta flags concerns over India's data law and rules as it expands AI and wearables push
search_results.snippet: Meta’s privacy chief Rob Sherman says the company is building a “specific consent experience” for India under its regulatory readiness program to meet the DPDP Act and soon‑to‑be‑notified 2025 rules. He flags open questions on limits to personalisation/profiling for under‑18s, cross‑border data transfers, and obligations for significant data fiduciaries, adding Meta will adapt products in India once rules are finalized.

search_results.title: CCI's ruling can force rollback of features, hurt business, warns Meta
search_results.snippet: Reuters reports Meta warned an Indian tribunal that the CCI’s November order imposes a five‑year ban on WhatsApp sharing user data with Meta for advertising, which could force rollbacks or pauses of features and prevent Facebook/Instagram from personalizing ads based on WhatsApp Business interactions. The order also requires WhatsApp to offer users a choice on sharing, and Meta has appealed.

search_results.title: WhatsApp Business Messaging Policy
search_results.snippet: WhatsApp’s official policy requires businesses to contact users only after obtaining opt‑in permission and to secure all necessary notices, permissions, and consents, maintain a privacy policy, and comply with applicable law. Outside the 24‑hour service window, only approved templates can be used, reflecting a consent‑first approach consistent with India’s DPDP requirements.

What penalties or restrictions did EU im.query: What penalties or restrictions did EU impose on Meta's Ad-Free Subscription offering in 2025?
What penalties or restrictions did EU im.answer: In April 2025, the European Commission found Meta’s “consent-or-pay” ad‑free subscription in breach of the DMA, fined Meta €200 million (covering March–November 2024), and required it to provide a less‑personalized but equivalent free alternative while ensuring freely given consent for any data combination. Meta was given 60 days to comply; the Commission warned that continued non‑compliance could trigger periodic daily fines of up to 5% of Meta’s average global daily turnover from 27 June 2025.

search_results.title: Commission finds Apple and Meta in breach of the Digital Markets Act
search_results.snippet: On 22 April 2025, the European Commission ruled Meta’s ‘consent or pay’ setup breached the DMA because it failed to offer users a less‑personalized but equivalent free service and did not allow freely given consent for data combination; it imposed a €200m fine for the March–November 2024 period and required compliance within 60 days or risk periodic penalty payments.

search_results.title: Meta may face daily fines over pay-or-consent model, EU warns
search_results.snippet: On 27 June 2025, citing the April non‑compliance decision and €200m DMA fine, the Commission warned that if Meta’s limited changes still fall short, it could levy periodic daily fines of up to 5% of Meta’s average daily worldwide turnover starting 27 June 2025.

search_results.title: EU: Meta Could Face Daily Fines If It Does Not Revise Ad Model
search_results.snippet: TechRepublic reports the EU fined Meta €200m in April 2025 over its 2024 ‘pay or consent’ model and gave 60 days to meet DMA requirements (including a less‑personalized but equivalent option), after which periodic penalty payments of up to 5% of average global daily revenue could begin from 27 June 2025.

What regulatory approvals are needed for.query: What regulatory approvals are needed for Meta's Constellation nuclear PPA and data center expansions in Illinois?
What regulatory approvals are needed for.answer: For the nuclear PPA, Constellation must secure U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission approvals tied to Clinton’s continued operation and planned changes — notably NRC license renewal beyond April 2027 (now under review) and approvals associated with the 30 MW uprate; Constellation also indicates it may seek NRC permits (early site permit extension or a new construction permit) if it pursues advanced nuclear at Clinton, with added output delivered in MISO Zone 4. For data center expansions (e.g., in DeKalb), local land-use approvals are required: city planning/zoning actions to add “data center” as a permitted use and amend annexation/development agreements, followed by City Council approvals of preliminary and final development plans before construction; local siting for a ComEd substation is addressed through the city process.

search_results.title: Meta, Constellation sign 20-year clean power deal
search_results.snippet: World Nuclear News reports Clinton’s license expires in April 2027 and Constellation has applied to the NRC for a 20-year extension, now under review. The Meta PPA supports relicensing and a 30 MWe uprate at Clinton — pointing to federal nuclear approvals as the key pathway for continued operation under the deal.

search_results.title: Constellation, Meta Sign 20-Year PPA Tied to Illinois Nuclear Plant
search_results.snippet: Constellation says the Meta PPA backs relicensing and a 30 MW uprate at Clinton, with added clean energy flowing into MISO Zone 4. The company is evaluating extending an existing early site permit or seeking a new NRC construction permit for possible advanced nuclear/SMR at the Clinton site, underscoring NRC approvals for both uprates and any new units.

search_results.title: Planning and Zoning Commission – City of DeKalb Minutes (July 15, 2024)
search_results.snippet: DeKalb’s Planning & Zoning Commission recommended adding “Data Center” as a permitted use and increasing allowable square footage, but noted any actual data center build still requires City Council approvals of preliminary and final development plans. Local approvals also address site planning and related utility siting (e.g., ComEd substation) before construction can proceed.

What steps is Meta taking to comply with.query: What steps is Meta taking to comply with Brazilian LGPD for AI-driven ad targeting in 2025?
What steps is Meta taking to comply with.answer: In 2025, Meta’s LGPD compliance in Brazil centers on transparency, user control, and governance for AI systems used in ads. After ANPD’s enforcement, Meta committed to notifying Brazilian users (via email and in-app) about AI data use, updating privacy notices, offering a simplified opt-out (including for non‑users), waiting 30 days before any such processing, and excluding minors’ data. In parallel, Meta is expected to align with ANPD guidance for generative AI by documenting DPIAs, strengthening technical/organizational safeguards, and providing clearer information about automated decision-making that underlies AI‑driven ad delivery and targeting.

search_results.title: Meta cumpre exigências da ANPD e poderá retomar, com restrições, o uso de dados pessoais para treinamento de inteligência artificial
search_results.snippet: ANPD approved a compliance plan requiring Meta to: notify Facebook and Instagram users with clear, accessible information about AI-related processing; update privacy notices and banners; provide a simplified form so users and even non‑users can object; observe a 30‑day notice period before using data; and refrain from using minors’ data. ANPD will monitor compliance and AI system implementation.

search_results.title: What Brazil's ANPD expects from companies using generative AI
search_results.snippet: ANPD’s guidance (Technology Radar No. 3) explains how LGPD applies to generative AI across data collection, training, use, sharing and deletion. It stresses purpose limitation, necessity, transparency and accountability, and recommends technical/organizational safeguards, governance and documentation (including DPIAs) to manage risks and support explainability and rights around automated decisions.

search_results.title: Brazil: Following data protection authority's demand, Meta will inform users how it intends to use their personal data to train generative AI
search_results.snippet: Reuters reports Meta will notify Brazilians by email and in-app about how their data may be used to train AI and allow them to opt out, after ANPD suspended its policy. The suspension was lifted once Meta agreed to disclosures; Meta also paused some generative‑AI features in Brazil while engaging with ANPD—moves aimed at transparency and user control under LGPD.

What is Meta's 2025 exposure to geopolit.query: What is Meta's 2025 exposure to geopolitical risk from U.S.-China tensions affecting app operations or ad demand?
What is Meta's 2025 exposure to geopolit.answer: Meta’s 2025 exposure is primarily to ad demand, not app operations, since its services are blocked in China. China-based advertisers contributed roughly 10–11% of Meta’s 2024 revenue (~$18.4B), making China its No. 2 revenue source. Analysts warn that tariffs and the end of the U.S. de minimis rule could cut Chinese advertisers’ spending on Meta by about $7B in 2025, with a severe scenario of up to ~$23B if tensions and macro weakness intensify.

search_results.title: Meta’s magnificence threatened by trade clash
search_results.snippet: Reuters Breakingviews reports Meta relies on Chinese advertisers for about 10% of revenue and had ~$18B (11%) in China-attributable revenue in 2024—despite having no presence in China; trade measures like ending duty-free de minimis shipments could force Temu/Shein and others to cut ad budgets, pressuring 2025 sales.

search_results.title: Meta's ad revenue from Chinese e-retailers at risk on trade worries, MoffettNathanson says
search_results.snippet: Reuters notes MoffettNathanson warns that escalating U.S.–China tensions and the end of the de minimis rule could curb Chinese e‑retailers’ ads on Meta; Meta’s China revenue was $18.35B in 2024 and $13.69B in 2023, highlighting meaningful exposure of 2025 ad demand to policy-driven pullbacks.

search_results.title: Meta may have a $7 billion problem in China
search_results.snippet: MarketWatch (Dow Jones) summarizes MoffettNathanson’s view that China accounted for ~11% of Meta’s 2024 revenue (~$18.4B) and that up to ~$7B of ad spend from Chinese marketers is at risk in 2025 from tariffs and trade frictions; a prolonged downturn plus trade war could push the hit as high as ~$23B.

What is Meta's 2025 legal exposure from.query: What is Meta's 2025 legal exposure from content moderation policy changes, including class actions or consumer claims?
What is Meta's 2025 legal exposure from.answer: Meta’s 2025 moderation shifts have drawn regulatory and litigation risk on multiple fronts. In the EU, the Commission’s preliminary DSA findings say Facebook and Instagram’s reporting and appeals systems breach the law, exposing Meta to potential fines up to 6% of global turnover if confirmed. In the U.S., consumer and civil‑rights claims are advancing—DC’s Equal Rights Center case over discriminatory ad delivery survived dismissal—and new class actions allege ad‑moderation failures, including impersonation scam ads that misuse professionals’ likenesses, signaling material exposure across regulatory, consumer-protection, and class-action avenues.

search_results.title: Commission preliminarily finds TikTok and Meta in breach of their transparency obligations under the Digital Services Act
search_results.snippet: On 24 Oct 2025, the European Commission issued preliminary findings that Facebook and Instagram violated the DSA by making ‘notice‑and‑action’ reporting and content‑moderation appeals overly complex and by using dark patterns, undermining illegal‑content removal. search_results.title: Equal Rights Center Wins Key Ruling in Fight Against Meta’s Alleged Discriminatory Ad Delivery Practice
search_results.snippet: On July 30, 2025, a DC court denied Meta’s motion to dismiss a lawsuit alleging its ad delivery steers for‑profit college ads to Black users while favoring public nonprofit college ads for white users, violating the DC Human Rights Act and the Consumer Protection Procedures Act. The ruling allows consumer and civil‑rights claims tied to Meta’s algorithmic and moderation practices to proceed, signaling exposure to discrimination and consumer‑protection liability.

search_results.title: Scott+Scott Files Lawsuit Against Meta Over Scam Impersonation Ads

The complaint asserts federal and state claims and seeks damages and injunctive relief, highlighting class‑action exposure tied to ad‑moderation and enforcement failures.

What are Meta's obligations under U.S. F.query: What are Meta's obligations under U.S. FTC orders in 2025 related to privacy, data retention, and advertising practices?
What are Meta's obligations under U.S. F.answer: In 2025, Meta remains bound by the FTC’s 2020 order. It must operate a 20‑year privacy program with independent board oversight, conduct and document privacy reviews for new or modified products, undergo independent assessments, and have executives certify compliance; it is prohibited from misrepresenting privacy practices. For data retention, the order requires cutting off third‑party access within 30 days after a user deletes data or an account and deleting or de‑identifying user‑entered content within 120 days, subject to limited exceptions. Advertising‑related limits include a ban on using phone numbers collected for security (e.g., 2FA) for ads and obtaining express consent for facial recognition uses that go beyond prior disclosures. The FTC has proposed additional restrictions (e.g., banning monetization of minors’ data and requiring assessor sign‑off before launches), but as of July 2025 that show‑cause proceeding was stayed, so the 2020 order remains the operative set of obligations.

search_results.title: Commission Order Modifying Order (2020) – Facebook, Inc. (C‑4365)
search_results.snippet: The binding 2020 FTC order sets Meta’s operative obligations: do not misrepresent privacy; provide clear notice and obtain affirmative express consent before sharing Nonpublic User Information beyond users’ settings; cut off Covered Third Party access within 30 days after a user deletes data or an account and delete or de‑identify user‑entered content within 120 days (with narrow exceptions); and do not use telephone numbers collected for account security (e.g., two‑factor authentication) for advertising.

search_results.title: FTC Imposes $5 Billion Penalty and Sweeping New Privacy Restrictions on Facebook
search_results.snippet: The FTC’s 20‑year order overhauls Meta’s privacy governance: an independent board privacy committee; designated compliance officers with quarterly and annual certifications; an independent assessor with biennial reviews; mandatory privacy reviews for every new or modified product; incident reporting for compromises affecting 500+ users; stronger third‑party app oversight; a ban on using 2FA phone numbers for ads; and clear notice and consent for facial recognition uses.

search_results.title: Facebook, Inc., In the Matter of (C‑4365) – FTC Legal Library
search_results.snippet: This case page compiles the controlling documents and 2025 status: it links to the 2020 order and the 2023 Order to Show Cause proposing to ban monetizing minors’ data and require assessor sign‑off before product launches; on July 30, 2025 the Commission stayed the show‑cause proceeding, indicating the 2020 order remains the operative obligations while the proposed modifications are pending.

How dependent is Meta's 2025 AI strategy.query: How dependent is Meta's 2025 AI strategy on Scale AI, and what are mitigation plans if partnership weakens?
How dependent is Meta's 2025 AI strategy.answer: Meta’s 2025 AI strategy is materially tied to Scale AI after a ~$14.3B investment (about a 49% stake) and bringing Scale’s CEO to lead Meta Superintelligence Labs, signaling reliance on Scale for high-quality training data and leadership. However, operational dependence is hedged: Meta’s core TBD Labs continues sourcing labeled data from rival vendors like Surge and Mercor and is simultaneously building out its own AI compute infrastructure. If the partnership weakens, Meta’s practical mitigations are to expand its multi-vendor data-labeling pipeline and lean on in-house capabilities and infrastructure rather than a single supplier.

search_results.title: Cracks are forming in Meta’s partnership with Scale AI
search_results.snippet: Two months after Meta’s $14.3B investment in Scale AI and hiring Scale leaders into MSL, sources say Meta’s TBD Labs is also using rival data-labeling vendors like Surge and Mercor—some researchers even prefer their data—showing Meta is not ‘all-in’ on Scale. The piece also notes Meta’s broader AI buildout (e.g., massive data centers), underscoring a multi-vendor, infrastructure-heavy strategy that inherently mitigates single-partner risk.

search_results.title: Scale AI confirms ‘significant’ investment from Meta, says CEO Alexandr Wang is leaving
search_results.snippet: Scale AI confirmed a substantial Meta investment valuing it at $29B, with reports pegging Meta’s stake at about 49%. Meta said the partnership will deepen joint work producing data for AI models, and Scale’s CEO Alexandr Wang moved to Meta to help lead its superintelligence efforts—evidence that Scale is a central pillar of Meta’s 2025 AI data strategy.

search_results.title: Scale AI Announces Next Phase of Company’s Evolution
search_results.snippet: Scale announced Meta’s investment (valuing Scale at over $29B) and a substantial expansion of their commercial relationship to accelerate Scale’s data solutions, while asserting Scale remains independent and safeguards customer data. The release confirms the deepened Meta–Scale alignment that Meta can leverage for data needs, even as Meta maintains options outside a single provider.

How will Apple's 2025 privacy changes or.query: How will Apple's 2025 privacy changes or ATT enforcement shifts impact Meta's signal loss and ad performance?
How will Apple's 2025 privacy changes or.answer: Apple’s 2025 updates tighten iOS/Safari privacy and keep attribution inside Apple’s privacy sandbox. Safari 26 turns Advanced Fingerprinting Protection on by default, limiting access to high‑entropy web APIs, referrer/query data for known tracker scripts, and long‑lived client storage—reducing deterministic web signals (including click-ID based attribution) that Meta relies on, and pushing more modeled, server-side measurement. Apple also upgraded AdAttributionKit with configurable windows, conversion tags, cooldowns, and limited geo in postbacks—helpful for app measurement but still aggregated and privacy‑preserving, not a return to user-level signals. Historically, ATT already degraded Meta ad effectiveness (e.g., a 37% CTR drop for conversion‑optimized campaigns and revenue hits for Meta‑dependent firms), so these 2025 shifts likely add incremental signal loss and optimization headwinds for Meta on iOS, especially for web‑to‑app and retargeting.

search_results.title: WWDC 2025: The Shiny, The Sharp, and the Subtle Shifts in Attribution and Privacy
search_results.snippet: Branch explains that at WWDC 2025 Apple expanded Safari’s anti‑tracking posture and detailed AdAttributionKit upgrades. Safari 26 will block known fingerprinting scripts from sensitive web APIs, using long‑lived storage, and reading navigational referrer/query parameters—weakening deterministic link attribution (e.g., click IDs like fbclid) and pushing platforms toward modeled measurement. Meanwhile AAK gains configurable attribution windows, conversion tags, cooldowns, and limited country codes for privacy‑preserving app attribution.

search_results.title: With iOS 26, Safari will counter one of the web’s most invasive tracking methods
search_results.snippet: Apple states that in iOS 26, Advanced Fingerprinting Protection is enabled by default across all Safari browsing. Safari injects noise and overrides outputs of fingerprint‑prone APIs, and applies per‑site/session fingerprints—curbing cross‑site tracking and making web identifiers less stable/visible. This reduces the deterministic web signals advertisers (including Meta) use for attribution and optimization on Safari traffic.

search_results.title: Evaluating the Impact of Privacy Regulation on E-Commerce Firms: Evidence from Apple's App Tracking Transparency
search_results.snippet: This April 2025 working paper finds ATT materially degraded Meta ad performance: conversion‑optimized Meta campaigns saw a 37% drop in CTR, spend shifted toward Google, and firms more dependent on Meta suffered 8–40% revenue declines. The results indicate stricter Apple privacy enforcement increases signal loss and hurts Meta’s ad effectiveness—context for how 2025 privacy changes may add further headwinds.

What cybersecurity incidents affected Me.query: What cybersecurity incidents affected Meta in 2025, and what changes were made to prevent similar breaches?
What cybersecurity incidents affected Me.answer: In 2025, Meta faced a targeted WhatsApp spyware campaign linked to Paragon that exploited a FreeType zero‑day (CVE‑2025‑27363); WhatsApp blocked the vector with a server‑side fix, requested a CVE, shared findings across the industry, and the bug was later patched in Android and added to CISA’s KEV list. Separately, a hacker claimed to have scraped 1.2B Facebook user records via a Facebook API; Cybernews verified a sample and Meta said it had already taken anti‑scraping steps. To harden accounts against credential abuse, Meta rolled out passkeys on Facebook for mobile (with Messenger support to follow), reducing phishing and password‑reuse risks.

search_results.title: FreeType Zero-Day Found by Meta Exploited in Paragon Spyware Attacks
search_results.snippet: WhatsApp confirmed a Paragon-linked spyware campaign exploited a FreeType zero‑day (CVE‑2025‑27363) in zero‑click attacks using group‑sent PDFs. Meta/WhatsApp mitigated the attack vector with a server‑side patch in late 2024, later requested a CVE, shared findings with the ecosystem, and Google patched Android; CISA added the flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.

search_results.title: Major Facebook data leak reveals 1.2 billion user records, hacker claims
search_results.snippet: A threat actor claimed to have scraped 1.2B Facebook user records by abusing a Facebook API, with a 100,000‑record sample (IDs, names, emails, phones, locations, birthdays, gender) appearing legitimate. Meta did not deny scraping but pointed to prior disclosures and said it had taken steps to prevent similar incidents, while researchers cautioned about verifying the dataset’s full scope.

search_results.title: Introducing passkeys on Facebook for mobile devices
search_results.snippet: On June 18, 2025, Meta began rolling out passkeys on Facebook for iOS and Android, with Messenger support to follow, enabling sign‑in via device biometrics or PIN instead of passwords. Meta positions passkeys as more resistant to phishing and credential‑stuffing, managed via Accounts Center, to strengthen account security against password‑based attacks.

What commitments has Meta made to UK ICO.query: What commitments has Meta made to UK ICO regarding children's safety, age assurance, and AI interactions in 2025?
What commitments has Meta made to UK ICO.answer: Following engagement with the UK ICO, Meta committed to roll out Teen Accounts on Instagram with high‑privacy defaults, tighter messaging controls and stronger parental supervision for under‑18s, and to ramp up age assurance by requiring more age verification and proactively identifying teen accounts. On AI, Meta said it would resume UK model training using only public content shared by adults, not information from UK users under 18, and would make objection/opt‑out simpler and more prominent for UK users, with the ICO monitoring compliance. These steps reflect child‑safety protections, strengthened age‑assurance practices, and tighter safeguards around AI data use affecting young people in the UK.

search_results.title: Building AI Technology for the UK in a Responsible and Transparent Way
search_results.snippet: Meta says that, after positive engagement with the ICO, it will begin training its generative AI in the UK using only public content shared by adults on Facebook and Instagram, explicitly excluding information from UK users under 18. It also commits to clearer transparency and a simpler, more prominent objection form for UK users, and notes the ICO’s guidance on legitimate interests as a legal basis.

search_results.title: Our statement in response to Meta's announcement to introduce teen accounts
search_results.snippet: The ICO welcomes Instagram’s new protections for younger users following its engagement with Meta, reiterating that under the Children’s code kids’ accounts must be set to ‘high privacy’ by default unless there is a compelling reason otherwise. The regulator says it will keep pushing industry to go further and take action where firms are not doing the right thing.

search_results.title: Teen Accounts Introduced to Instagram
search_results.snippet: UK Safer Internet Centre partner SWGfL explains Instagram’s Teen Accounts: default private posts and restricted messaging (only from accounts teens follow), parental supervision tools (time limits, approvals), and stricter content settings. It adds that Meta will require more age verification across platforms and build technology to proactively find teen accounts, with UK rollout within 60 days.

What content or advertiser boycotts impa.query: What content or advertiser boycotts impacted Meta in 2025, and what remediation steps were taken?
What content or advertiser boycotts impa.answer: In 2025, the most concrete advertiser boycott affecting Meta was Canada’s federal ad freeze, which ended in February when Ottawa resumed buying ads on Facebook and Instagram despite Meta still blocking news links in Canada. Separately, Meta’s January moderation rollback sparked calls from advocacy groups like GLAAD for advertisers to boycott, but trade reporting indicated no broad ad pullback. To mitigate brand risk concerns, Meta executives engaged advertisers, emphasizing brand-safety and suitability controls and direct outreach (e.g., Nicola Mendelsohn’s communications), while continuing to offer tools and, historically, policy exceptions for major advertisers.

search_results.title: Federal government is once again advertising on Meta platforms
search_results.snippet: Canada’s federal government ended its boycott of advertising on Meta in Feb. 2025, confirming up to $100,000 in ad spend on Facebook and Instagram for a GST/HST campaign, even though Meta continues to block news links in Canada; the ad freeze began in July 2023 over the Online News Act dispute.

search_results.title: Meta’s pullback on fact-checking puts brand safety back in the spotlight
search_results.snippet: After Meta ended U.S. fact-checking and relaxed hateful-conduct rules in Jan. 2025, agency leaders said clients weren’t broadly pulling spend; ahead of any pushback, Meta’s Nicola Mendelsohn told advertisers the company would keep investing in brand-safety and suitability tools, and the piece notes Meta has historically made policy exceptions for large advertisers.

search_results.title: Meta's new policies open gate to hate
search_results.snippet: Following Meta’s moderation changes allowing more anti‑LGBTQ and other controversial speech, GLAAD condemned the move and urged advertisers to “stand up and walk away,” highlighting calls for an advertiser boycott and raising questions about how brands would react to the newly permitted content.

What contingency plans exist if the Cons.query: What contingency plans exist if the Constellation nuclear PPA faces delays or regulatory challenges before 2027 deliveries?
What contingency plans exist if the Cons.answer: Constellation obtained an NRC exemption in 2019 granting ‘timely renewal’ protection with a three‑year filing window, so Clinton can continue operating beyond its April 17, 2027 license expiration until the NRC issues a final decision—mitigating the risk that administrative delays affect 2027 deliveries. NRC’s review is largely complete, further reducing delay risk. The Meta–Constellation PPA beginning June 2027 is for clean energy attributes rather than direct physical delivery; beyond the timely‑renewal safeguard, no explicit contingency plans are publicly detailed.

search_results.title: Clinton Power Station, Unit 1 – Exemption from 10 CFR 54.17(a) (allows timely renewal with 3‑year filing)
search_results.snippet: In 2019 the NRC granted Clinton Unit 1 an exemption from 10 CFR 54.17(a)/2.109(b), allowing a license renewal application at least three (not five) years before expiration to still receive ‘timely renewal’ protection—meaning the plant can continue operating past April 2027 until the NRC’s final decision, avoiding shutdown due solely to administrative delay.

search_results.title: Clinton Power Station, Unit 1 – License Renewal Application cover letter (Feb. 14, 2024)
search_results.snippet: Constellation’s cover letter states Clinton’s current operating license “is set to expire at midnight on April 17, 2027” and cites the NRC’s 2019 exemption that permits a three‑year filing to retain timely‑renewal protection; it asserts the application meets the approved timeliness allowance.

search_results.title: Constellation, Meta Sign 20-Year PPA Tied to Illinois Nuclear Plant
search_results.snippet: The Meta–Constellation 20‑year PPA begins in June 2027, supports relicensing and continued operations after state ZECs end, and has Meta purchasing the plant’s clean energy attributes while the unit continues to feed the local grid—indicating an attributes‑based contract rather than direct physical delivery.

What are Meta's 2025 GPU supplier alloca.query: What are Meta's 2025 GPU supplier allocations between NVIDIA, AMD, and custom accelerators for training and inference?
What are Meta's 2025 GPU supplier alloca.answer: Meta has not published exact 2025 supplier percentages. Public disclosures indicate training remains NVIDIA‑heavy (H100/H200 clusters moving to GB200 racks), while inference is increasingly split between AMD Instinct MI300X systems and Meta’s own MTIA inference accelerators. In short: 2025 training ≈ NVIDIA; 2025 inference ≈ AMD + MTIA, with NVIDIA GPUs still present.

search_results.title: Building Meta’s GenAI Infrastructure
search_results.snippet: Meta details two 24k‑GPU clusters used to train Llama 3 and says its 2024 build‑out includes 350,000 NVIDIA H100s and total compute equivalent to nearly 600,000 H100s—evidence that large‑scale training is centered on NVIDIA as Meta scales into 2025.

search_results.title: Our next-generation Meta Training and Inference Accelerator
search_results.snippet: Meta describes MTIA as its custom inference accelerator, now deployed in production for ranking and recommendation workloads and designed to complement current and future GPUs—showing Meta will use in‑house silicon alongside merchant GPUs for inference in 2025.

search_results.title: Meta Announces AMD Instinct MI300X for AI Inference and NVIDIA GB200 Catalina
search_results.snippet: At OCP 2024, Meta said it brought AMD’s MI300X to its Grand Teton platform for inference and is already using these systems, while also adopting NVIDIA’s GB200 ‘Catalina’ rack next—signaling AMD for inference and NVIDIA for next‑gen training into 2025.

How significant are energy price and ava.query: How significant are energy price and availability risks to Meta's 2025-2027 AI data center operations?
How significant are energy price and ava.answer: High and material. Meta is already locking in long‑term, firm power (e.g., a 20‑year, 1.121‑GW nuclear PPA starting in 2027) to de‑risk AI loads, while local grid build‑outs for new campuses face regulatory pushback and long lead times (e.g., Louisiana gas plants). Industry forecasts indicate that by 2027 up to 40% of AI data centers could be constrained by power and electricity prices are likely to rise, implying schedule risk and higher operating costs for Meta in 2025–2027 despite mitigation steps.

search_results.title: Meta, Constellation ink 20-year nuclear power deal to support AI goals
search_results.snippet: Meta signed a 20‑year PPA for 1,121 MW of nuclear power from Constellation’s Clinton plant beginning in June 2027 to support AI ambitions. The deal secures firm, clean baseload and reflects Meta’s need to hedge against grid constraints and energy price risks as AI data center power demand grows.

search_results.title: Environmental groups move to block power supply for Meta’s planned Louisiana AI data center
search_results.snippet: Two groups filed motions to block Entergy’s plan to build three gas plants (2.26 GW) and major transmission for Meta’s proposed 2 GW Louisiana AI data center. With generation targeted for 2028–2029 and billions in costs at issue, the case underscores energy availability and rate risks that can delay energization and raise operating costs.

search_results.title: Power Shortages Will Restrict 40% of AI Data Centers By 2027 – Gartner
search_results.snippet: Gartner forecasts that by 2027, 40% of AI data centers will be constrained by power availability and that electricity prices will rise as operators compete for supply. Short‑term power shortages and long lead times for new generation and transmission point to materially higher price and availability risks across the AI data center sector.

What long-term power purchase agreements.query: What long-term power purchase agreements beyond Constellation support Meta data centers in 2025 by region?
What long-term power purchase agreements.answer: In 2025, beyond Constellation, Meta signed long-term PPAs with AES for 650 MW of solar in the Southwest Power Pool (Texas and Kansas), with RWE for 200 MW at Waterloo Solar in Texas (ERCOT) plus recent PPAs in Illinois and Louisiana, and with ENGIE North America expanding to 1.3 GW across Texas including the 600 MW Swenson Ranch Solar. These contracts support Meta’s data centers across ERCOT (Texas), SPP (Texas/Kansas), and extend coverage into MISO/PJM via Illinois and Louisiana.

search_results.title: AES and Meta Sign Long-Term PPAs to Deliver 650 MW of Solar Capacity in Texas and Kansas
search_results.snippet: AES announced two long-term PPAs totaling 650 MW of solar to support Meta’s data centers, with projects brought online in the Southwest Power Pool (SPP) serving Texas and Kansas—explicitly adding new generation in these markets to back Meta’s operations.

search_results.title: RWE and Meta sign long-term power purchase agreement for offtake from 200 MW energy project in Texas
search_results.snippet: RWE and Meta entered a long-term PPA for 100% of the 200 MW Waterloo Solar project in Bastrop County, Texas (ERCOT), and RWE notes it is the third recent long-term contract with Meta across three U.S. states, following PPAs in Illinois and Louisiana.

search_results.title: ENGIE and Meta expand Power Purchase Agreements to more than 1.3 GW in U.S with addition of new 600 MW solar project
search_results.snippet: ENGIE North America said Meta will take 100% of output from the new 600 MW Swenson Ranch Solar in Texas and expand their PPAs to more than 1.3 GW across four Texas projects, explicitly to support Meta’s U.S. data center operations in ERCOT.

What is Meta's 2025 dependency on Apple.query: What is Meta's 2025 dependency on Apple and Google app stores, including fees and policy risks?
What is Meta's 2025 dependency on Apple.answer: Meta remains heavily dependent on Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android ecosystems for distributing and monetizing its apps in 2025. Its 2024 Form 10-K warns that changes to third‑party mobile operating systems, app stores, and browsers (e.g., Apple and Google) continue to impact ad targeting/measurement and could harm growth, due to policy shifts like Apple’s ATT, billing rules, and review/steering restrictions. App store fees directly affect Meta’s pricing: Meta prices its EU ad‑free subscription higher on iOS/Android than on the web to reflect Apple/Google store charges, and Apple’s policy requires in‑app ‘boosted posts’ purchases to use IAP, subject to up to a 30% cut, which Meta passes on or routes users to the web to avoid.

search_results.title: meta-20241231 - SEC.gov
search_results.snippet: Meta’s 2024 Form 10-K notes that changes to the regulatory environment and to third‑party mobile operating systems, app stores, and browsers (e.g., Apple iOS and Google Android) have impacted and will continue to impact advertising signal availability, targeting/measurement, and monetization; Meta depends on these platforms for distribution and is exposed to policy shifts (such as Apple’s ATT), app review and billing rules, and other platform requirements that could harm user growth, engagement, and revenue.

search_results.title: Facebook and Instagram to Offer Subscription for No Ads in Europe | Meta
search_results.snippet: Meta explicitly states that its iOS/Android subscription price is higher to “take into account the fees that Apple and Google charge through respective purchasing policies,” illustrating direct exposure to app store fees (e.g., €9.99/month on web vs €12.99/month on iOS/Android at launch, later reduced to €5.99 vs €7.99), and demonstrating how Apple/Google store economics affect Meta’s pricing and monetization.

search_results.title: Apple Responds to Meta's Plan to Charge 30% Fee on Boosted Posts Purchased Through App Store
search_results.snippet: After Apple clarified that ‘boosted posts’ are a digital service requiring in‑app purchase, Meta said iOS boosts will be billed via Apple and subject to up to a 30% cut, with advertisers pushed to prepay or use the web (Facebook.com/Instagram.com) to avoid the fee. This underscores Apple policy risk for Meta’s in‑app ad tools and the direct impact of App Store commission rules.

Which contract manufacturers assemble Me.query: Which contract manufacturers assemble Meta's servers in 2025, and what capacity expansions are planned?
Which contract manufacturers assemble Me.answer: In 2025, Meta’s servers are primarily assembled by Quanta Computer and Wiwynn. Economic Daily News reports Quanta holds about half of Meta’s server orders, while Wiwynn derives over half of its revenue from Meta. Meta also reportedly awarded Quanta final assembly of its next‑gen ASIC AI servers (“Santa Barbara”) with up to 6,000 racks slated to roll out from late 2025. On capacity, Wiwynn is expanding with a US$300m Texas factory and increased capex in Taiwan alongside existing Mexico/Malaysia sites, while Quanta is the named assembler for the Santa Barbara ramp.

search_results.snippet: TrendForce, citing Economic Daily News and Reuters, reports Meta will deploy up to 6,000 racks of a next‑gen custom ASIC AI server (code‑named Santa Barbara) starting late 2025–2026, with Broadcom supplying the ASICs and Quanta Computer (with a Taiwanese chassis partner) handling final assembly—evidence that Quanta is a key Meta server assembler in 2025.

search_results.title: Wiwynn Corp announces plan to invest US$300m to build a facility in Texas - Taipei Times
search_results.snippet: Wiwynn—listing Meta and Microsoft as major clients—announced a US$300m plan to build its first US manufacturing facility in Texas and raised capex for a new Taiwan plant, expanding global capacity alongside existing Mexico and Malaysia sites to meet AI server demand and tariff-driven reshoring.

search_results.title: 微軟、Meta加碼AI 台鏈振奮 鴻海、廣達、緯穎等伺服器鏈喜迎商機 | 經濟日報
search_results.snippet: Economic Daily News notes Quanta is Meta’s primary contract manufacturer, holding around 50% of Meta’s server orders, while Wiwynn gets over 50% of its revenue from Meta—identifying the two firms as Meta’s core 2025 server assemblers amid rising AI capex.

Which optics and networking vendors supp.query: Which optics and networking vendors supply Meta's 400G/800G switches and transceivers in 2025?
Which optics and networking vendors supp.answer: For switching, Meta’s 400G ToR platforms are built with Cisco’s Silicon One (Wedge400C) and Broadcom Tomahawk3 (Wedge400), with Celestica as the ODM manufacturing partner. search_results.title: Introduction of Meta network hardware - Wedge 400
search_results.snippet: Meta’s Wedge400 ToR (16×400G + 32×200G) uses Broadcom Tomahawk3 and FBOSS. search_results.title: 800GbE Optics Shipments to Grow 60% in 2025
search_results.snippet: Cignal AI’s 2025 Optical Components Report identifies Innolight, Coherent, and Eoptolink as the largest suppliers of 400G/800G datacom modules for hyperscalers, with Lumentum and Broadcom among key optical component sources. It notes 800GbE optics are the fastest‑growing segment in 2025.

What 2025 operating margin impact stems.query: What 2025 operating margin impact stems from server useful life extension to 5.5 years at Meta?
What 2025 operating margin impact stems.answer: Approximately a 1.7–1.8 percentage-point lift to 2025 operating margin. Meta disclosed that extending the useful life of certain servers and network assets to 5.5 years will reduce 2025 depreciation by about $2.9 billion; against $164.5 billion of 2024 revenue (and higher expected in 2025), that translates to roughly 170–180 bps of margin tailwind.

search_results.title: Meta Reports Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2024 Results
search_results.snippet: Meta’s Jan 29, 2025 IR release says it increased the estimated useful life of certain servers and network assets to 5.5 years starting FY2025, and expects this to cut 2025 depreciation by about $2.9B; it also reports 2024 revenue of $164.5B and a 42% operating margin, providing context for the margin effect.

search_results.title: Meta Platforms tweak accounting formula on AI servers to boost profit
search_results.snippet: Bloomberg-reported piece notes Meta extended useful life for certain servers and networking assets to five and a half years (from four to five), and estimates the change will reduce 2025 depreciation by $2.9B—nearly 4% of estimated pre-tax profits—with the impact likely larger in 2026.

search_results.title: Meta Platforms extends estimated life of certain servers, network assets
search_results.snippet: Summary of Meta’s January disclosure: the company increased the estimated useful life of certain servers and network assets to 5.5 years effective 2025, and expects the change to reduce full-year 2025 depreciation expense by roughly $2.9B.

What are Meta's 2025 contractual terms w.query: What are Meta's 2025 contractual terms with data labeling providers, including volumes, pricing, and SLAs?

search_results.snippet: Reuters reports Meta was in talks in June 2025 to invest over $10 billion in data-labeling startup Scale AI, with deal terms not finalized and subject to change. What HBM supply commitments did Meta sec.answer: For 2025, Meta locked in HBM via Broadcom-led ASIC programs: SK hynix is set to ship HBM in 2H25 for Broadcom’s AI chips built for Meta, and Samsung’s HBM3E cleared Broadcom QA with deliveries targeted from late 2025.
