search_results.title: Micron close to selling all the high-bandwidth memory it will make in 2026
search_results.snippet: Micron told investors it now has six HBM customers and has already locked pricing agreements for the vast majority of its HBM3E supply in calendar 2026 while negotiating HBM4 volumes, effectively committing its 2026 output to customers.

search_results.title: Samsung Slashes HBM3E 12Hi Production by Half Amid Delayed NVIDIA Approval
search_results.snippet: Citing ZDNET Korea, the report says Samsung’s 12‑Hi HBM3E passed Broadcom’s quality tests and it is negotiating >10bn Gb shipments, with deliveries to Broadcom expected to start by late 2025 for AI ASICs used by clients such as Google and Meta.

search_results.title: SK hynix has major HBM order to Broadcom: which is making AI chips for Google, Meta, ByteDance
search_results.snippet: TheElec-sourced report says SK hynix will deliver a large HBM order to Broadcom in 2H 2025, with the memory used in Broadcom AI chips for cloud customers including Meta—indicating Meta’s 2025 HBM was secured via SK hynix through Broadcom.

What water usage reduction technologies.query: What water usage reduction technologies are deployed in Meta's 2025 data centers, and which vendors supply them?
What water usage reduction technologies.answer: Meta reduces water use primarily by deploying the StatePoint Liquid Cooling (SPLC) system co-developed with Nortek Air Solutions, which uses a membrane liquid-to-air exchanger and cuts water consumption by >20% in hot/humid climates and up to ~90% in cooler climates versus earlier indirect systems. Meta also uses indirect evaporative cooling at scale—Munters supplied Oasis IEC units for Facebook/Meta’s Clonee (Ireland) and Odense (Denmark) data centers—and employs energy‑efficient evaporative cooling at Luleå, Sweden using Condair ME units. Together, these vendor-supplied systems minimize or avoid mechanical cooling, improve water efficiency, and support Meta’s 2030 water‑positive goals.

search_results.title: StatePoint Liquid Cooling system: A new, more efficient way to cool a data center
search_results.snippet: Meta describes deploying the StatePoint Liquid Cooling (SPLC) system, co-developed with Nortek Air Solutions, which uses a liquid‑to‑air membrane exchanger to produce chilled water and reduce water use versus prior indirect systems. Based on testing, SPLC can cut water consumption by more than 20% in hot/humid climates and by almost 90% in cooler climates, while maintaining PUE comparable to or better than direct evaporative cooling; SPLC feeds fan‑coil walls, in‑row/rear‑door heat exchangers, and even chip cooling.

search_results.title: MUNTERS RECEIVES DOUBLE DATA CENTER COOLING ORDER
search_results.snippet: Munters confirmed two significant orders to supply its Oasis Indirect Evaporative Cooling (IEC) units to Facebook’s data centers in Clonee, Ireland (phase 3) and Odense, Denmark (phase 2). The Oasis IEC solution—based on Munters’ polymer heat‑exchanger—replaces compressor‑based cooling for much of the year and is used by Meta to achieve highly efficient, low‑water cooling at scale in European facilities.

search_results.title: Facebook Data Center, Luleå
search_results.snippet: Condair states that its Condair ME evaporative cooler is used at Facebook’s Luleå data center to deliver energy‑efficient evaporative cooling in the cold‑climate site. The solution leverages indirect evaporative techniques to reduce mechanical cooling demand, identifying Condair as a vendor supplying Meta’s evaporative cooling hardware at Luleå.

How diversified are Meta's 2025 headset.query: How diversified are Meta's 2025 headset supply chains for Quest, including displays, lenses, and assembly partners?
How diversified are Meta's 2025 headset.answer: Meta’s 2025 Quest supply chain is moderately diversified. On displays, teardown analysis indicates Meta multi-sources LCD panels for Quest 3S/Quest 2–class screens from JDI, BOE and possibly Sharp. Lens sourcing is more concentrated: Meta built the pancake-lens supply chain itself and a key reported supplier for Quest 3 is Genius Electronic Optical (GSEO), suggesting fewer mature vendors. Assembly is anchored by Goertek, with production shifting from China to Vietnam in 2025, expanding geographic diversification while relying on the same core ODM.

search_results.title: Meta’s Quest 3S is just a revamped Quest 2, and it’s the better for it | iFixit
search_results.snippet: iFixit’s Quest 3S teardown shows the same RGB stripe LCD as Quest 2 and notes Meta is expected to source panels from multiple vendors—JDI, BOE, and possibly Sharp—indicating a multi-supplier display pipeline rather than single-sourcing.

search_results.title: Meta Pushes Back on Reported Outsourcing of XR Headset Designs | Road to VR
search_results.snippet: Reporting on The Information’s scoop, Road to VR says Meta plans to move roughly half of Quest manufacturing from China to Vietnam, with Goertek as a key ODM/assembly partner. Meta’s CTO confirms Goertek remains a major partner—showing geographic diversification (Vietnam) but continued reliance on the same assembler.

search_results.title: Apple AR supplier will reportedly make lenses for Meta's Oculus Quest 3 | AppleInsider
search_results.snippet: Analyst Ming‑Chi Kuo reported that Genius Electronic Optical (GSEO) secured significant lens orders for Meta’s next high‑end Quest headset (Quest 3), indicating Meta’s lens supply includes GSEO and reflects reliance on specialized optics vendors.

What is Meta's 2025 unit economics for R.query: What is Meta's 2025 unit economics for Reels ads versus Feed ads, including cost and revenue per minute?
What is Meta's 2025 unit economics for R.answer: Meta has not published 2025 ‘unit economics’ with exact cost and revenue per minute by format. Management frames the goal as improving “revenue generated per minute of Reels watched,” and has repeatedly said Reels monetizes per time below Feed while the gap narrows. CFO Susan Li added that Reels is more video‑intensive, with different ad load and slower scroll, which depresses monetization per time versus Feed; she declined to quantify the gap. Third‑party benchmarks indicate that as of late 2024 Reels CPMs remain materially below Instagram Feed (about 38% lower) even as Reels approaches 20% of impressions—implying Reels’ revenue per minute still trails Feed in 2025, while Meta has not disclosed any per‑minute cost figures.

search_results.title: Digital Ads Benchmark Report by Tinuiti | Q3 2024 | Key Highlights
search_results.snippet: Tinuiti’s Q3 2024 data shows Reels’ share neared one in five Instagram ad impressions and that Instagram Reels CPM remained well below Feed—about 38% lower in Q3 2024—indicating Reels’ monetization per impression (and thus per time) still trails Feed even as Reels’ share rises.

search_results.title: Meta Platforms, Inc. (NASDAQ:META) Q4 2022 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg explicitly defined the Reels goal as improving “revenue generated per minute of Reels watched” and said Reels’ monetization efficiency was much less than Feed; the plan was to reach revenue neutrality and then grow profitably as per‑minute monetization improves.

search_results.title: Facebook, Instagram Reels plays ‘more than doubled’ in 2022, but monetization lags
search_results.snippet: CFO Susan Li said Meta isn’t quantifying the monetization‑efficiency gap, noting Reels is more video‑intensive with slower scroll and different ad load—factors that hold back monetization efficiency per time versus Stories and Feed despite strong engagement growth.

How much of Meta's 2025 expense growth i.query: How much of Meta's 2025 expense growth is infrastructure versus headcount, and what hiring freezes exist?

search_results.title: Meta Reports Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2024 Results

search_results.title: Report: Meta is hitting pause on AI hiring after its poaching spree
search_results.snippet: After an aggressive recruitment campaign, Meta froze hiring in its AI organization, confirming the pause as “basic organizational planning” following a reorg of Meta Superintelligence Labs into four groups (superintelligence, products, infrastructure, long-term research).

What construction contractors are buildi.query: What construction contractors are building Meta's 2025 U.S. data center campuses, and what timelines are committed?

search_results.title: Meta to open $800m data center in Rosemount, Minnesota

How are Meta's diversity and inclusion m.query: How are Meta's diversity and inclusion metrics trending in 2025 across leadership and technical roles?
How are Meta's diversity and inclusion m.answer: In 2025, Meta dismantled core DEI infrastructure—ending representation goals, stopping the ‘Diverse Slate’ hiring approach, sunsetting supplier diversity, and disbanding its DEI team. With role-level targets removed and programs scaled back, Meta hasn’t released new breakdowns by leadership or technical roles, and experts cited by Axios note that companies dropping such goals typically see slower progress or declines. Taken together, the 2025 changes point to stalling or backsliding in representation across leadership and technical roles versus the gains Meta reported in prior years.

search_results.title: Read: Meta's memo to employees rolling back DEI programs
search_results.snippet: An internal memo confirms Meta ended representation goals for women and ethnic minorities, will stop using the ‘Diverse Slate Approach’ in hiring, sunset supplier diversity, and disband the DEI team while shifting to “cognitive diversity.” This removes role-level targets and formal DEI mechanisms that previously underpinned gains across leadership and technical roles.

search_results.title: Well yeah, ending diversity programs probably means less diversity
search_results.snippet: Axios reports research showing firms with representation goals make more progress than those without, and a Harvard expert says Meta’s changes will likely reduce workforce diversity. The piece notes Meta had met earlier diversity pledges, implying the 2025 rollback risks backsliding in representation across leadership and technical roles.

search_results.title: Meta ends its DEI programs as Zuckerberg blasts Biden on Joe Rogan
search_results.snippet: CNN confirms Meta is ending DEI programs, eliminating its DEI team, changing hiring practices, and no longer requiring managers to seek candidates from underrepresented groups. The company frames the move as a response to the evolving legal landscape, signaling a retreat from the targets and practices that supported prior diversity gains.

What is the 2025 headcount plan by funct.query: What is the 2025 headcount plan by function at Meta, including engineering, sales, and trust and safety?
What is the 2025 headcount plan by funct.answer: Meta’s 2025 plan concentrates hiring in engineering/technical roles: R&D across infrastructure, monetization, Reality Labs, and generative AI, with CFO Susan Li noting nearly 90% of recent headcount growth was in R&D and that 2025 growth will be primarily technical. Business functions like sales/marketing are expected to see relatively limited headcount growth. Meta is also executing performance-based cuts of roughly 5% with the intention to backfill roles in 2025, while later in the year it began automating parts of risk/compliance (trust and safety-adjacent) work, leading to reductions in Product Risk, Shared Services, and Global Security & Privacy teams.

Which internal decision-making forums ap.query: Which internal decision-making forums approve major AI capex at Meta in 2025, and their meeting cadence?
Which internal decision-making forums ap.answer: In 2025, major AI capex at Meta is ultimately approved by the Board of Directors as a “significant transaction,” with oversight and recommendations routed through two Board committees. The Board meets on a quarterly cadence (with special meetings as needed). The Risk & Strategy Committee reviews strategic initiatives (including technology and asset utilization) and sets its own meeting frequency (meets as needed). The Audit & Privacy Committee oversees significant financial matters and product/regulatory compliance (including generative AI) and is required to receive quarterly briefings, effectively creating at least a quarterly cadence.

search_results.title: Corporate Governance Guidelines (Effective June 1, 2025) | Meta Investor Relations
search_results.snippet: The Board acts as management’s adviser, monitors performance, and “reviews and, if appropriate, approves significant transactions,” setting standards for what must be escalated to the Board. It also specifies meeting cadence: “Typically one regularly scheduled meeting of the Board should be held each quarter, plus special meetings as required.”

search_results.title: Risk & Strategy Committee Charter (Effective June 1, 2025) | Meta Investor Relations
search_results.snippet: This Board committee assists with oversight of company risk and strategy, including reviewing strategic initiatives spanning technology, product development, and asset utilization, and recommending alignment of growth with risk exposures. The charter notes the Committee decides its own meeting frequency, i.e., it meets as needed.

search_results.title: Audit & Privacy Committee Charter (Effective June 1, 2025) | Meta Investor Relations
search_results.snippet: The committee oversees accounting and financial reporting, the independent auditor, and significant financial matters, as well as product/regulatory compliance including cybersecurity, youth wellbeing, integrity, and generative AI. While the committee sets its own meeting frequency, it must receive briefings “each quarter,” establishing at least a quarterly cadence.

report:
# META (Meta Platforms, Inc.) — Equity Research Report

## 1) Investment Recommendation Summary
- Stance: BULLISH
- Rating: BUY
- Next Market Day view (after Q3’25 results on Oct 29, 2025): Modestly positive skew. We think clarity on 2025–2026 AI capex financing and resilient ad KPIs can offset spend concerns. Base case: in-line-to-slight beat and reaffirmed FY25 capex range with reiterated partner-financing plans → +1% to +3% move; downside if 2026 capex ramps more than expected without offsetting financing clarity → −4% to −6% potential.

## 2) Executive Summary
Meta enters Q3’25 earnings with:
- Solid ad monetization momentum (double-digit ad impression growth and high single-digit price per ad in Q2) and scale advantages across 3.48B DAP, providing a strong revenue base [3].
- A very heavy AI infrastructure build (FY25 capex $66–$72B; “similarly significant” dollar growth expected in 2026) balanced by a net cash balance sheet and increasing use of partner/project financing to limit corporate leverage [1][2][3][4][5][21][22][23].
- A 2025 depreciation tailwind from extending server/network useful lives to 5.5 years (reduces 2025 depreciation by ~$2.9B), partially offset by an expected acceleration in depreciation in 2026 as AI assets come online [7][15][17][6][8].

Near term, we expect investors to focus on: (i) FY25 capex and early 2026 spend framework, (ii) ad KPI trajectory and revenue durability, (iii) Reality Labs (RL) loss run-rate, and (iv) monetization roadmaps for Meta AI. We recommend BUY based on scale-driven ad cash flows, disciplined funding structures for AI capex, and optionality from AI/premium services, while acknowledging near-term volatility around AI spend.

## 3) Company Overview
- What it does: Operates Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Messenger with monetization primarily via digital advertising; develops AR/VR hardware/software via Reality Labs; investing heavily in AI infrastructure and foundation models [15].
- Segments: Family of Apps (FoA) and Reality Labs (RL) [15].
- Scale and profitability context: FY2024 revenue $164.5B and 42% operating margin, demonstrating earnings power prior to the AI capex surge [15].

## 4) Key Findings by Category

### A) Revenue and Monetization
- Scale and engagement: Q2’25 Family DAP reached 3.48B (+6% YoY), ad impressions +11% YoY, average price per ad +9% YoY — a constructive setup for sustained ad revenue growth [3].
- Mix: Ads remain ~98% of revenue (Q1’25), underscoring concentration in the ads engine [2]. Non-ad revenue (FoA “Other” + RL) was ~2% of revenue in Q1’25 (~$922M of $42.3B) and ~2% in Q2’25 (~$953M of $47.5B), indicating early-stage diversification [10][11].
- AI monetization: Meta signaled a future “premium service” for Meta AI (more compute/functionality) in addition to ads/product recommendations; near-term focus is scaling engagement before monetization [12]. We view this as medium-term optionality layered atop the core ads engine.

### B) Capital Allocation, Leverage, and Liquidity
- Capex: FY25 capex guided to $66–$72B (including finance leases), with 2026 to see “similarly significant” dollar growth to bring more AI/data center capacity online; majority of 2025 capex goes to the core business [1][2][3][6].
- Buybacks and dividends: Robust capital returns alongside heavy capex. Q1’25: $13.4B repurchases, $1.33B dividends; Q2’25: $9.76B repurchases, $1.33B dividends [1][2][9]. Run-rate implies substantial ongoing capital return even during the AI build.
- Reality Labs: RL posted a $4.53B operating loss on $370M revenue in Q2’25, highlighting continuing RL investment drag on consolidated results [1].
- Leverage/liquidity: End-Q2’25 cash and marketable securities $47.07B vs. $28.8B debt (net cash); no formal leverage target disclosed [3]. Meta is increasingly deploying external/project financing (e.g., Blue Owl JV for Hyperion; reports of a ~$29B asset-backed package) to maintain balance-sheet flexibility [4][5][22]. The company also reclassified ~$2.04B of DC land/construction as “held-for-sale” to contribute to partners within 12 months — another tool to share AI infrastructure costs [23].

Our take: Meta is prioritizing capex to secure AI leadership while preserving balance-sheet strength through partner-financing and asset-backed structures. We expect this to cap corporate leverage and protect buyback capacity.

### C) Costs, Depreciation, and Margins
- 2025 expense drivers: The largest driver of expense growth is infrastructure costs (including higher depreciation); second-largest is employee compensation as Meta adds technical talent across infra, monetization, RL, genAI, and compliance [14].
- Depreciation dynamics: Meta extended useful lives of certain servers/network assets to 5.5 years effective 2025, expected to reduce 2025 depreciation by ~$2.9B — a tailwind to GAAP margins this year [7][15][17]. However, 2026 will see a sharp acceleration in depreciation expense growth as AI infrastructure ramps [6][8].

Implication: 2025 operating margin should benefit from the useful life change, while 2026 margins will be pressured by faster D&A — reinforcing the need for revenue/monetization traction from AI to hold consolidated margins.

### D) AI Infrastructure and Compute Scale
- 2025–2026 buildout: FY25 capex upshift (to $66–$72B) is largely AI/data-center related [1][2]. Meta expects to field >1.3M GPUs by YE’25, underlining the magnitude of training and inference capacity being deployed [18].
- Baseline: Meta targeted 350,000 NVIDIA H100s by YE’24, with total compute equivalent to nearly 600,000 H100s — indicating training is predominantly NVIDIA-GPU based [19].
- 2026+ clusters: Prometheus AI supercluster targeted to come online in 2026; Hyperion in Louisiana can scale to 5GW over several years (with significant milestones through 2027+) [13][20]. Construction for the Richland Parish (Louisiana) campus is slated to ramp in late summer 2025 via Turner/DPR/Mortenson [24].

### E) Funding the 2026–2027 Capex Ramp
- Strategy: Management expects to self-fund most AI spend but is pursuing partner co-development and asset-backed financing to attract significant external capital to the data center program [21].
- Evidence: The Blue Owl JV (80/20) and reports of ~$29B financing for Hyperion (including ~ $26B in asset-backed debt) point to concrete mechanisms that can offload peak funding needs while preserving net cash [4][5][22]. The ~$2.04B “held-for-sale” reclassification of data-center assets supports this approach [23].

### F) Segment D&A visibility
- No segment-level D&A guidance: Management flagged higher infrastructure-driven depreciation as the largest expense driver in 2025 and an acceleration in 2026, but did not provide FoA vs. RL D&A splits [6][7][8]. This limits precision in modeling RL vs. FoA margin trajectories.

### G) Sensitivity to Ad Pricing
- With ads ~98% of revenue in Q1’25, changes in price per ad largely flow through the top line [2].
- Simplified 2025 sensitivity: A ±5% change in price per ad implies roughly a ±5% move in ad revenue (and ~±5% in total revenue, given the mix). Given high fixed-cost absorption, we estimate a meaningful operating margin swing (directionally 150–250 bps), depending on the incremental margin assumption. This illustrates the leverage Meta has to pricing vs. relatively less variable COGS, especially in-year [2]. 

### H) Debt maturities and buyback authorization
- Debt maturity schedule/avg interest rate: Not detailed in the cited Q2 release. Q2 shows continued buybacks and dividends with net cash intact [9][3].
- Remaining buyback authorization and cadence: The Q2 release confirms ongoing repurchases but does not disclose remaining authorization. H1’25 repurchases totaled ~$23.2B, demonstrating an active cadence [1][2][9].

## 5) Investment Thesis

### Bull Case
- Scale advantages in engagement and first-party data continue to support ad auction health; Q2’25 KPIs (ad impressions +11%, price per ad +9%, DAP +6%) indicate durable monetization momentum [3].
- 2025 margin tailwind from depreciation life extension (~$2.9B reduction) provides near-term earnings resilience as AI spend ramps [7][15][17].
- Funding discipline reduces balance-sheet risk: net cash at Q2, growing use of partner/project financing (Blue Owl JV; asset-backed structures) should preserve buybacks and dividends even as 2026 capex rises [3][4][5][21][22][23].
- Optionality from AI: Meta’s plan for a premium AI service in addition to ads/product recommendations creates a monetization vector beyond the core ads engine, while business messaging/subscriptions show early diversification [12].

### Bear Case
- RL burn remains heavy (Q2’25 loss $4.53B on $370M revenue), and 2026 depreciation is set to accelerate materially, risking consolidated margin compression if AI monetization lags [1][6][8].
- Ads concentration (≈98% of revenue in Q1’25) leaves results sensitive to macro-ad cycles and pricing; any deterioration in ad demand or pricing could deleverage margins [2].
- Execution/supply risk: AI cluster buildouts depend on timely GPU supply (heavily NVIDIA), power delivery, and construction execution; delays could push out model roadmaps and ROI [19][18][24].
- Capex fatigue: If FY26 capex steps up more than anticipated without greater external financing or near-term revenue benefits, multiple compression risk rises.

## 6) Key Risks
- Monetization timing risk for AI assistants/features; “premium service” roadmap is early-stage [12].
- Capex/opex overrun risk in 2026 (infrastructure costs and depreciation) versus revenue realization [6][8][14].
- RL profitability timeline uncertainty; sustained large RL losses [1].
- Financing execution risk with partners/asset-backed structures and potential cost of capital volatility [4][5][21][22][23].
- Ad market cyclicality; sensitivity to price-per-ad changes [2].
- Supplier concentration in NVIDIA for training-scale compute [19][18].

## 7) Conclusion and Outlook
- Rating: BUY (BULLISH)
- Next market day (10/30/25) setup: We expect a modestly positive reaction if management (i) reaffirms FY25 capex ($66–$72B) and frames 2026 as “similarly significant” but increasingly financed via partnerships/asset-backed structures, (ii) shows continued ad KPI strength, and (iii) signals disciplined RL spend trajectory [1][2][3][6][21][22][23]. 
- FY25–FY26 margin trajectory: 2025 benefits from ~$2.9B less depreciation, while 2026 faces a sharp D&A step-up as AI capacity goes live; that places a premium on ad pricing/mix and initial AI monetization traction to stabilize consolidated margins [7][15][17][6][8].
- Medium-term outlook: The combination of scale-driven ad cash generation, disciplined external financing for AI infrastructure, and optionality from AI premium/enterprise features supports upside potential. We see a constructive risk/reward into and after Q3’25, with volatility tied to capex contours and the pace of AI commercialization.
